Award.AwardTitle: Self-Esteem Threat as a Moderator of the Mechanism Underlying Exaggerated Positivity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates why people so consistently view themselves through rose-colored glasses. What exactly are people thinking when they claim that their personalities are more desirable then they actually are -- or that they've achieved more than they actually have? Some researchers claim that these rosy views come about because people simply want to feel good. Instead of acknowledging their negative aspects, people focus more on their good qualities when evaluating themselves. Other researchers claim that consistently rosy self-views have less to do with the goal of feeling good and more to do with evaluating one's self in the quickest and easiest manner possible. Many of people's decisions and judgments are based on the first thing that comes to mind. Further, many times, the first thing that comes to mind happens to flatter the self -- which makes it appear as though people are striving to make themselves look good.

The proposed project attempts to integrate the "hot" (motivational) perspective and the "cold" ("what's on your mind?") perspectives on overly favorable self-views -- by suggesting that both are correct under different conditions. The key may be that people approach an evaluation of themselves differently depending on whether there is a recent challenge to their positive feelings about themselves. For example, people faced with recent criticism may restore their positive feelings by emphasizing their positive qualities when describing themselves. However, when those same people find themselves in situations that do not challenge their positive feelings, they may use the first thing that comes to mind to describe themselves. If that happens to be self-flattering, they will make the same rosy claims but for very different reasons.

The proposed studies will investigate (a) how criticism shapes how deeply people have to think to make rosy claims about themselves, (b) how criticism affects people's willingness to consider information beyond that which comes to mind easily, and (c) exactly which brain regions support people's rosy views of the self. The results will help reconcile the competing views on why people so often make rosy claims about themselves. Additionally, the results may point out an exception to current theories about how people's emotions influence their thoughts (e.g., fear may not always make people think harder) and will expand the psychological understanding of how the brain supports the human sense of self.

As shown in past research, the common tendency for people to see themselves through rose-colored glasses has long-term costs for health, education, and workplace performance. For example, people who fail to acknowledge health problems and health risks do not seek appropriate treatment. Further, many clinical disorders involve unrealistic beliefs about the self -- such as substance abusers' beliefs that they can use "just this once" without relapsing or narcissists' beliefs that they are superior to others. People who are overconfident about their academic ability or work skills also perform poorly in school and at work. By identifying exactly when and why people are most likely to view themselves accurately, versus through rosy lenses, this research can inform interventions that will help people better decide when they should seek treatment, study harder, or allow more time to complete an important task.

This project will also advance the scientific training of students at the undergraduate and graduate levels. In addition, the results will be broadly disseminated because the lab interfaces with psychologists, neuroscientists, economists, and professionals in the fields of medicine and law through publications, academic presentations, Continuing Education (CE) presentations, and training programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project helped advance our knowledge about why people often lack self-insight, and in particular, why this lack of insight tends to take on an unrealistically positive twist. Why does it matter if people don't know themselves? Although there can be benefits to wearing rose-colored glasses, a failure to be honest with oneself is costly for society because overconfident people undermine their school success, work performance, and health by overestimating their abilities and by failing to take negative feedback into account. If we want to help people enjoy the benefits of seeing oneself through rose-colored glasses and avoid the costs, then we need to understand what causes the lack of insight in the first place. Furthermore, many mental health issues arise from poor self-insight yet current neural models of these disorders only focus on emotional problems. Successful intervention and treatment require a more complete neural model of the underlying psychological factors.

This project specifically resolved a longstanding debate on why people tend to see themselves in a unrealistically positive light and provides new avenues for thinking about how to combat poor self-insight. Previously, one school of thought suggested that people defend their self-esteem by failing to acknowledge negative aspects of themselves. Another school of thought suggested that self-esteem defense was not necessarily the driving force of this lack of self-insight. Instead, this perspective emphasized that people just don't want to think very hard. In this case, they may use the first thought about themselves that comes to mind when evaluating their capabilities and that often tends to be positive in nature.

This project found that, by adulthood, it is not mentally taxing for people to evaluate themselves in an overconfident manner regardless of whether they are motivated by the desire to defend their self-esteem or simply do not put in a lot of thought to their self-evaluations. So self-esteem defense and low mental effort are not mutually exclusive. Yet the project did find that self-esteem defense shapes the mental avenue through which people arrive at overconfident self-evaluations. Specifically, the neural basis of overconfidence is different depending on whether it arises from a desire to defend self-esteem or not. An application of computational modeling to the neural data further showed that when people are motivated to defend their self-esteem, they tend to purposefully overemphasize feedback, memories, or information that will make them look good. Other studies showed that people do not even encode unflattering information to begin with. Therefore, efforts to combat poor self-insight arising from self-esteem defense will need to aid people in taking in unflattering information to begin with and also helping them appropriately weigh unflattering information when evaluating one's abilities. It should be noted that these findings also have implications for the field of cognitive neuroscience which had not previously examined the neural basis of poor self-insight.

In addition to advancing knowledge about why self-insight tends to be lacking and neural models of self-evaluation, the project also had wide-reaching implications for education. Specifically, numerous trainees including those from underrepresented populations received interdisciplinary training in psychology, cognitive neuroscience, and computational modeling. These trainees ranged from undergraduates to postdoctoral researchers both within and outside the United States. Additionally, the findings were disseminated in popular media as well as peer-reviewed academic journals in the fields of psychology and cognitive neuroscience. Finally, the findings were used to educate professionals in leadership positions in corporations who were interested in better understanding how to help employees accurately assess their abilities to improve work performance.
